Different classes of materials have been proposed as SSEs, among which are complex hydrides.
1, 7 Lithium borohydride (LiBH 4) has been extensively studied as an SSE, thanks to a remarkable ionic conductivity (σ) above 120 °C, combined with a low density (0.666 g/cm 3). In fact, the LiBH 4 RT-polymorph has an orthorhombic unit cell, space group (s.g.) Pnma, showing low Li-ion conductivity (10 –8 S cm –1), while around 110 °C,
8 it shows a polymorphic orthorhombic-to-hexagonal (s.g. P6 3 mc) transition, rising the ionic conductivity of several orders of magnitude (∼10 –3 S cm –1 at 120 °C).
9 Recently, LiBH 4 has been reported to be electrochemically stable up to about 2 V versus Li +/Li,
10, 11 reducing the value of 5 V versus Li +/Li previously overestimated.
